abstract.p: Letter from Marci A Hamilton says Supreme Court's recent decision invalidating civil remedy provision of Violence Against Women Act should serve as reminder to Congress that it is supposed to be national body serving national interests

Re ''Court and Congress,'' by Anthony Lewis (column, May 20): There is nothing ''dubious'' about the history of the Supreme Court's federalism cases.

The framers believed that the most dangerous branch would be the federal legislature and that the separation of powers should apply not only to the federal branches but also to the federal government and the states.

Congress has lost all sight of its role. The court's recent cases, including the case invalidating the civil remedy provision of the Violence Against Women Act, are actually a mild reminder to Congress that it is supposed to be a national body serving national interests. The court should be applauded for its courage in drawing the constitutional boundaries around Congress, not chided for being ''headstrong.''
MARCI A. HAMILTON New York, May 23, 2000
The writer is a professor at Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law.
